results.title: 'Rivers of fire': an eruption of Hawaii's Mauna Loa Volcano
results.creator_credit: Les Malzman, Jon Erickson, Kathleen English, United States. National Park Service and Hawaii Natural History Association
results.brief_description: Examines the twenty two day eruption of Mauna Loa, the world’s largest volcano which started on 25 March 1984. Explains the Hawaiian volcanoes with spectacular photography within a well structured presentation which includes excellent graphics of plate tectonics and the hot spot theory.
results.title_for_label: ‘Rivers of fire’: an eruption of Hawaii’s Mauna Loa Volcano
results.creator_credit_for_label: Les Malzman, Jon Erickson, Kathleen English, United States. National Park Service and Hawaii Natural History Association

results.title: 'Moomba' 1973 - 'Float parade' thru' the city
results.brief_description:
The Pallaris Collection contains 16mm colour footage of the Moomba parades in Melbourne from the 1950s to 1970s. Most films were shot by aspiring filmmaker John Christofi Pallaris, while some are credited to Reg Robinson.

Moomba Festival held its inaugural event through the streets and parks of Melbourne on 12 March 1955. The festival was designed as a public cultural event for the city, incorporating a street parade, a carnival and an outdoor art show, among other festivities. Throughout the 1950s to 1970s the grand parade down Swanston Street was at its peak, attracting crowds of hundreds of thousands of people and featuring a stream of decorated floats on flat-bed trucks advertising businesses and community groups, accompanied by marching bands, celebrities, clowns, and performers on stilts. The crowning of Moomba monarchs who lead the parade has been a tradition since 1955.

This 16mm film shows footage of the 1973 Moomba parade at the intersection of Victoria and Swanston Streets and captures the parade and crowds of onlookers as it passes through the city.

At the beginning of the film we see the 1973 King of Moomba, Sir Doug Nicholls (Yorta Yorta, 1906 – 1988), waving to the crowd from the back of a car, followed by the Queen of Moomba, Janice Bridgeford. Sir Doug Nicholls was a celebrated football player, pastor, and activist for First Peoples rights, and one of the founders of the Federal Council for Aboriginal Advancement (later the Federal Council for the Advancement of Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders). He became Governor of South Australia in 1976 and was knighted in 1977.

The camera then follows the procession of floats, dancers, baton twirlers, stilt walkers, clowns, and other entertainers as they pass through the crowds of people down Swanston Street. Notable floats include the Wizard of Oz, Malta Travel Service, Clarke Mobile Cranes, Four’nTwenty Pies and ATV0, ‘Australia’s Action Station’.

results.title: 'Estampa flamenca'
results.creator_credit: Dave Ellis and Dave Ellis Films
results.brief_description: This film features Maria Benitez, one of the world’s great flamenco dancers, in rehearsal and performance in her native New Mexico. She discusses the Gypsy and Spanish origins of flamenco with members of her dance company, Estampa Flamenca. Narrated by Jose Rodriguez
results.description: This film features Maria Benitez, one of the world’s great flamenco dancers, in rehearsal and performance in her native New Mexico. She discusses the Gypsy and Spanish origins of flamenco with members of her dance company, Estampa Flamenca. Narrated by Jose Rodriguez

results.title: 'Moomba' 1974 - 'Float parade' thru' the city
results.brief_description:
The Pallaris Collection contains 16mm colour footage of the Moomba parades in Melbourne from the 1950s to 1970s. Most films were shot by aspiring filmmaker John Christofi Pallaris, while some are credited to Reg Robinson.

Moomba Festival held its inaugural event through the streets and parks of Melbourne on 12 March 1955. The festival was designed as a public cultural event for the city, incorporating a street parade, a carnival and an outdoor art show, among other festivities. Throughout the 1950s to 1970s the grand parade down Swanston Street was at its peak, attracting crowds of hundreds of thousands of people and featuring a stream of decorated floats on flat-bed trucks advertising businesses and community groups, accompanied by marching bands, celebrities, clowns, and performers on stilts. The crowning of Monarch royals who lead the parade has been a tradition since 1955.

This 16mm film shows footage of the 1974 Moomba parade through Melbourne, filmed at the corner of Victoria and Swanston Streets, opposite the City Baths. The parade begins with a marching band, followed by Disney cartoon characters Captain Hook and Mr Smee from Peter Pan, and Goofy. The 1974 Queen of Moomba Marianne Perrott appears on a decorative blue float, seated in a throne behind the distinctive white swan.

The camera then follows the rest of the parade, featuring entertainers, celebrities and characters such as Humphrey B. Bear, Daryl Somers and Ossie Ostrich, and a particularly impressive display of decorated floats and performances. Some of the notable appearances include Waltons department store, a group of Michelin men, the new Holden Torana with a sign reading “just in time for Moomba”, ATV0 ‘Australia’s Action Station’, Bendigo Pottery featuring a potter making ceramics on a wheel, Jewel Box, the Royal Children’s Hospital Pied Pipers, a Ukrainian Easter float, a Chinese dragon dance, Whittlesea District Mini Bike Club, and the Hungarian Square Dancing Association.

results.title: 'Murder ahoy'
results.creator_credit: George Pollock, Lawrence P. Bachmann and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
results.brief_description: A sea-going whodunit where the intrepid Miss Marple finds herself investigating events on the HMS Battledore, a navy training ship designed to give young hoodlums a chance at new lives. Miss Marple discovers some-one is training the delinquents to be good thieves instead of good citizens and is willing to kill to keep the fact quiet! Murder Ahoy features a rogues gallery of suspects and ingenious means of despatching victims including strychnine-laced snuff, a poisoned mousetrap and a noose from a yard-arm. Starring Margaret Rutherford, Lionel Jeffries and Stringer Davis.

results.title: 'E'
results.creator_credit: Brent Walker Film Productions, Robert Forget and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Under the guise of a pretty fairy tale, this animated film makes a strong political statement. Paper cut-outs enact a drama in which a dictator, suffering from a visual defect which affects his perception of things, imposes his delusions on his unfortunate subjects. The humour is black and despite an absence of dialogue the message is clear. (Awards: Berlin, Cracow, Zagreb, Gijon, Barcelona, New York)

results.title: 'Moomba' 1972 - 'Float parade' thru' the city.
results.brief_description:
The Pallaris Collection contains 16mm colour footage of the Moomba parades in Melbourne from the 1950s to 1970s. Most films were shot by aspiring filmmaker John Christofi Pallaris, while some are credited to Reg Robinson.

Moomba Festival held its inaugural event through the streets and parks of Melbourne on 12 March 1955. The festival was designed as a public cultural event for the city, incorporating a street parade, a carnival and an outdoor art show, among other festivities. Throughout the 1950s to 1970s the grand parade down Swanston Street was at its peak, attracting crowds of hundreds of thousands of people and featuring a stream of decorated floats on flat-bed trucks advertising businesses and community groups, accompanied by marching bands, celebrities, clowns, and performers on stilts. The crowning of Moomba monarchs who lead the parade has been a tradition since 1955.

This 16mm film features footage of the 1972 Moomba parade. Filmed at the intersection of Victoria and Swanston Street, opposite the City Baths, the camera follows the parade on its path through the city towards the Shrine of Remembrance.

That year’s Queen of Moomba, Debra Scott, leads the parade on a large decorative float with a white swan at the forefront, seated on a throne of pink petals. The parade then follows, including entertainers, celebrities and decorated floats on flat-bed trucks and cars, showcasing businesses and community groups. Some of the notable floats include Philippine Airlines, Kyneton Historical Centre, Gemini 12, Warburton Tourist Attractions, Theatres of Moscow, the Gold Coast, and a Chinese dragon dance. Towards the end of the parade, the King of Moomba John Farnham appears in a purple velvet suit seated in a horse-drawn carriage.

Content warning: this film includes brief footage of clown Zig (Jack Perry) in the parade, wearing blackface clown make-up. In 1994 Perry was convicted of sexually assaulting his granddaughter 20 years earlier, and in 1999 Zig and Zag were dethroned from their position as Moomba Monarchs.

results.title: 'M' [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Fritz Lang, Seymour Nebenzal and Nero-Film
results.brief_description: Peter Lorre in his greatest role portrays a psychotic child molester - a pathetic vagabond figure who experiences a frenzy at the sight of tender young school girls, and try as he may, he is unable to control the fervour of his criminal inclinations. The police disregard his letters of confession to them as the work of a lunatic, leaving the underworld to take the law into their own hands. The stylised realism of the sets and the detachment with which the opposing forces of law and outlawry are portrayed place this now classic film within the ambit of the so-called ‘new objectivity’ which was a reaction in Germany to the expressionist movement. This version is the longest available.

holdings.name: 16mm film; Access Print (Section 1)

results.title: 'A'
results.creator_credit: Renate Duhr, Jan Lenica and Argos Films Borresholm
results.brief_description: A bitter, pessimistic cartoon, showing man’s utter helplessness in the face of forces stronger than himself. A man’s home is invaded by the letter “A”. Guile, flattery, magic, brute strength fail to remove this enemy. He gives up all hope - then discovers that “A” has disappeared. After a period of doubt he is delighted to be alone again. Suddenly “B” appears! In fine line pen-and-ink style reminiscent of 19th century engraving, Jan Lenica has created a visual joke based on one of Eugene Ionesco’s quotations. The letters also symbolise privacy, oppression or one’s own problems. (Awards: Grand Prize for Film Animation, Oberhausen Festival)

constellations_primary.name: Suburban scenes (Lisa McCune)
constellations_primary.description: Lisa McCune is best known for her role as Constable Maggie Doyle in the television series Blue Heelers (1994–2006). In addition to showing the day-to-day lives of police in a small Victorian town, the series explores the various dynamics of suburbia—a theme present throughout the whole of screen media.

The letters also symbolise privacy, oppression or one’s own problems. (Awards: Grand Prize for Film Animation, Oberhausen Festival)
description_for_label: A bitter, pessimistic cartoon, showing man’s utter helplessness in the face of forces stronger than himself. A man’s home is invaded by the letter “A”. Guile, flattery, magic, brute strength fail to remove this enemy. He gives up all hope - then discovers that “A” has disappeared. After a period of doubt he is delighted to be alone again. Suddenly “B” appears! In fine line pen-and-ink style reminiscent of 19th century engraving, Jan Lenica has created a visual joke based on one of Eugene Ionesco’s quotations. The letters also symbolise privacy, oppression or one’s own problems. (Awards: Grand Prize for Film Animation, Oberhausen Festival)
